We will also explore theapplications of NetSci in various domains such as Telecom, Biology, Economics,etc.We will discuss the following topics:- Graph Theory and Social Networks- Mathematics of Networks- Network Models- Game Theory- Network Dynamics- Information Networks and the World Wide Web- Strategic Network Formation- Learning and Networks- Applications of Network Science in various domains

name: Music through Computer Programming
description: Interdisciplinary course designed for students of different disciplines including Arts, Commerce, Science, Engineering and Management.All concepts required will be taught from Scratch. Continuous and discrete variables. Sampling theorem and minimum sampling frequency requiredFrequency ratios of Equi-tempered and 22 shruti scalesStudy of phase modulation to implement a sound rich in harmonics. Additive synthesis .Study of frequency spectrum. FFT used to verify harmonics in phase modulated signals and additive synthesized signalsPiecewise linear functions to implement ADSR for musical notes. The course will enable the students to generate musical melodies through computer programming. One  interesting application of computer programming to music is to  to generate melodies automatically. Other applications like---  music synthesizer and mimicking physical instrument sounds will be studied Students will  write programs to implement these applications.

name: Chemical Technology and Calculations
prerequisite: ENR205 Thermodynamics - I [333]AND ENR210 Continuum Mechanics [2619]
description: The chemical process industries are widely encountered and play a crucial role in an industrial scenario. This course will enable understanding of chemical and physical processes, in a variety of industries. Students will be familiarized with fundamental principles and calculations employed in the industry that involve basics of material and energy balances as applied to processes and plants. Flow sheets related to several sectors, e.g. petroleum, pulp and paper, pharmaceutical, fertilizer, cement, waste processing, effluent treatment, and many others will be studied which will introduce various operations that are employed and the flow scheme of the entire plant. Various modes of operation and consequences of disruptions will be examined. Scale model making and CAD model making will be integral to the course.

name: Chemistry in the Engineering World
description: This course introduces chemistry in the context of engineering applications whose details are taught in later courses. Chemistry aspects and basics related to a variety of applications, such as, fuels, fertilizers, water, displays, (OLED), polymers, energy (battery, fuel cells), beverages, nutrition, semi-conductors, metals and alloys, oils, detergents, paints, pollutants, foods, and medicines, amongst others. When studying these topics, students will be trained on use of state-of-the-art instruments applicable to the sector. Implications of chemistry on technological advances will be illustrated.

name: Continuum Mechanics
prerequisite: Additional Instructions: The student must be familiar with high school mathematics such as calculus and algebra
description: This course lays foundation for fundamental theories of continuum mechanics with applications to various disciplines. After defining material and spatial coordinate systems, definitions of various properties of a continuum field are developed. Displacement gradients, strain and stress tensors are defined and explained with associated theories, such as, Hooke’s law for elasticity and plasticity. Yield criteria and plasticity will be covered with practical applications. Balance principles for mass, momentum and energy are discussed with applications. Constitutive equations for different types of materials, including solids, fluids, such as, viscous fluids, Newtonian fluids, plastics, etc. are introduced, along with practical applications from various fields.

name: Engineering Thermodynamics
description: This course builds up on the concepts of continuum and balance laws taught in continuum mechanics course, with classical thermodynamics treatment of the First and Second laws, irreversibility and availability, and behaviour of a pure substance and equations of state (and online data). Both control mass and control volume approaches will be considered. Applications of these concepts in energy conversion, particularly power and refrigeration cycles, will be discussed. Energy sources and their uses, and societal and environmental impacts will be discussed.

name: Linear Algebra Laboratory
description: In this beginner level course, concepts of linear algebra are covered via MatLab/SciLab based practice. Topics include: fundamentals of vectors and vector space, matrices and its operations: addition, subtraction, multiplications, division, matrix types. Systems of linear equations. Gauss elimination and Gauss-Jordan methods. Linear dependence and rank of a matrix. Determinant. Cramer’s rule.  Matrix inverse, diagonalization, orthogonalization, LU factorization. Eigenvalues and eigenvectors. These concepts will be illustrated with applications, such as, electric circuits, piped fluid systems/piping network, graphical projections such as planes, lines and rotations, stress analysis, heat transfer, traffic flow, structures, and others.

name: Materials and the Engineering World
description: Starting with history, the course will look at the evolution of materials, their applications, and processing using the compendium Cambridge Engineering Selector as a guide. Physical, chemical and biological properties will be discussed. These properties will be connected with the science of material structure, such as, crystals and grains, at different length scales. Standards of materials designation will be introduced, as also how these materials are available in the market. Hands-on laboratory work will give experience of measuring material properties, and structure of materials. Engineering uses and environmental aspects of the products will be integrated into the course.

name: Digital Electronics and Microprocessors
description: The course has two parts. One part centers around a computer board which is interfaced to input and output devices and explores the use of Analog to Digital converters and Digital to analog converters and the operations through a computer program. The second part involves the study of architecture of microprocessors. The functions of - data and address bus , program counter, stack pointers , registers and arithmetic logic units  and control unit will be studied. The distinction between serial and parallel I/O operations will be explored. The concept of interrupts will be studied. Introduction to assembly language programs will be given  and sample programs will be studied .Since computerized measurement and control is now present in all the branches of Engineering this foundation for the same will be highly useful for students of all the Engineering disciplines

name: Mechanics of Rigid Bodies
prerequisite: Additional Instructions: The student must be familiar with high school mathematics
description: This course introduces the fundamental principles of modelling and analysis of a rigid body and rigid multi-body mechanical system. The course emphasizes problem-solving and the students develop critical thinking skills and proficiency in analysis and use of computational tools, preparing them to address real-world engineering challenges in mechanical systems. Key topics include kinematics of a rigid body and rigid multi-body systems, degrees of freedom, force and moments, free-body diagrams, deriving equations of motion using Newton’s laws and Euler’s equation, and energy-based methods, motion analysis and visualization including numerical solutions of equations of motion.

name: Sensors, Instruments and Experimentation
description: This course gives knowledge and hands-on skills about sensors, instrumentations, and their interfacing with computers. Basics of uncertainty analysis are introduced and practised in experiments. Laboratory exercises involve sensor and instrument construction and principles of operation along with specifications/data sheets of manufacturers. Hands-on exercises include installation, calibration, operation, and interfacing with computers/DAS. A variety of instruments and sensors for physical quantities will be considered, such as, temperature, pressure, force, torque, strain, displacement, velocity, acceleration, voltage, current, flow rate, illumination, sound level, etc. Phases of experimentation will be introduced and students will experience these when executing a project experiment.

name: Design, Innovation and Making
description: Students work in teams that start with customer needs, societal relevance, and problem identification resulting in a project proposal. The second phase, includes development of concept deigns, evaluation of alternative designs, and concept design finalization. Various design techniques, e.g. TRIZ, Poka Yoke, FMEA, etc. and materials selection using CES are used to prepare engineering drawings resulting in a complete engineering design including Bill of Materials (BoM). To realize the design, techniques of DFM, DFA, are applied and manufacturing drawings are prepared. After making or buying the components, the assembly is carried out to realize the proof-of-concept. After testing, the products are displayed in an expo. Finally, manuals are prepared, and recyclability aspects are addressed.

name: Computer Vision: Modern Methods and Applications
prerequisite: CSE106 Basic Programming Languages [250]AND CSE210 Data Structures and Algorithms [339]AND CSC523 Machine Learning/CSE523 Machine Learning [663]AND MAT142 Introductory Calculus [2320]ORCSE100 Fundamentals of Computer Programming [1146]AND CSE205 Data Structures [1286]AND MAT281 Multivariable Calculus [1920]AND MAT281 Multivariable Calculus [2770]
description: Computer vision (CV) extracts semantics and descriptions from images or videos. It helps us analyse and understand the world by allowing visual perception in the artificial intelligent agent. CV is vital in healthcare, mobility, security, entertainment, and robotics. The major thrust of the course is to provide students with the foundation to understand basic CV algorithms, develop models, and put them into practice on images and videos. It allows them to translate ideas from theory to practice.

name: Machine Learning Theory and Practice
prerequisite: MAT142 Introductory Calculus [1166]AND CSE210 Data Structures and Algorithms [339]AND STA100 Probability [1327]ORCSE100 Fundamentals of Computer Programming [1146]AND CSE205 Data Structures [1286]AND MAT281 Multivariable Calculus [1920]AND MAT281 Multivariable Calculus [2770]
description: Welcome to a CSE 623 course on Machine Learning Theory and Practice. It introduces machine learning algorithms in supervised, unsupervised, and reinforcement learning. The course helps to develop computational thinking and strengthen programming skills to apply machine learning to problems in diverse domains.

name: Deep Learning
prerequisite: MAT142 Introductory Calculus [1166]AND STA101 Introductory Statistics [1273]
description: This deep learning course offers a comprehensive dive into advanced Artificial Intelligence  (AI) techniques. Students will learn about core architectures like Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs), which have applications in spatial data processing like images and videos.  The architectures of Recurrent Neural Networks (RNNs) will provide an understanding of sequence data processing like speech or text. The course also covers optimization methods, deep generative models like Generative Adversarial Networks (GANs), and transformative technologies such as transformers and large language models (LLMs) used in Natural Language Processing (NLP). The curriculum extends into computer vision (CV) and explores hybrid models combining multiple neural architectures for the processing of vision and language together.

name: Applied Data Science
prerequisite:
Additional Instructions: CSE605 Advanced Data Structures and Algorithms;
CSE500 Statistical Learning
description: This course covers the fundamentals of data science and its relevance in the real-time applications. Students will learn about data acquisition, cleaning, and preprocessing techniques, including web scraping and handling missing data. Exploratory data analysis techniques followed by an introduction to data mining using tree-based and ensemble classifiers will be covered in the course. Students will explore big data technologies like Hadoop and Apache Spark, advanced data visualization, storytelling with data, and time series analysis. The course will be taught through activity-based learning where students apply their skills to real-world data challenges, showcasing their understanding of data exploration, analysis, modeling, and presentation.

name: Data Science Lab
prerequisite:
Additional Instructions: -	Advanced Data Structures and Algorithms
-	Applied Statistics 
-	AI Lab
description: This course will be helpful in building real-time data science applications by implementing the concepts learnt in other theory courses related to data science. Students will learn about various tools and their usefulness in the data science modeling. They will use various tools for these such as SimPy (Simulation in Python) and TensorFlow. Using these tools and various datasets, they will develop data science models.

name: Product Dissection and Realization
description: This course imparts knowledge on the study of products with emphasis on generating bill of materials, part naming and numbering, their materials of construction and processes of manufacture. Aspects of mechanical, electrical, electronics, and civil engineering, amongst others, and design and ergonomics are experienced. Students practice a variety of hands-on manufacturing operations, followed by making of a multi-part, multi-process components to realize a product. Processes of manufacture include, but are not limited to machining, 3D printing, joining and welding, weaving, casting, finishing and painting, using materials, such as, mild steel, aluminium, wood, polymeric materials, concrete mixes, and fabrics, amongst others.

name: Engineering Visualization and Drawing
description: This course develops the ability to think and communicate pictorially. Concepts of perspectives, orthogonal projections, sectional views, and assembly drawings will be introduced. Free-hand sketching, and making drawings with graphics and CAD software will be extensively practiced. Skills on making animations using animation and CAD software will be imparted. Methods of dimensioning and use of standard symbols in mechanical, electrical, architectural, and process plants of will be introduced. AR/VR tools will be used to augment visualization. The importance of CAD in product design will be introduced via small projects.

name: Computer Organization and Architecture
prerequisite: ECE209 Digital Design [652]ORCSE213 Digital Logic with Hardware Description Language [2616]
description:
●	Instruction Set Architecture (ISA): Basics of RISC and CISC Architectures; Basics of Harvard and von-Neumann Architectures; Instruction format; Addressing Modes; Instruction Set for one example microprocessor (AVR/MIPS/load-store/RISC [RISC-V]) covering these category of instructions: Data Transfer; Arithmetic; Logical; Branching; Subroutine; Stack; Basic I/O and Interrupt; 
o	Assembly language programming (using ATMEL Studio or RARS simulator for RISC-V or MARS for MIPS)
●	Architecture of micro-computer/Central Processing Unit (CPU): Concept of control bus, address bus and data bus. Understanding the organization of the building blocks of micro-computer: Data memory, Instruction Memory, Register Set, Address decoding, Arithmetic-logic Unit (ALU), timing pulse generator, Program Counter (PC), Stack Memory and stack pointers, I/O registers, control unit**, to achieve the ISAo	**Design of control unit: Hardwired Control (MUX based and FSM based), Microprogrammed Control (ROM based)o	Design a multi-cycle non-pipelined RISC processor using a digital logic simulation tool (Logisim) and also in Verilog HDL (use of softcore RISC-V)●	I/O and Memory Organization: Memory hierarchies and organization; Cache*** and virtual memory & pages; I/O interfaces; Memory and I/O addressingo	***Cache Mechanisms (direct mapping, block based direct mapping, associate, and set associate), Cache replacement policies (LRU, LRU counter based, FIFO), (Implement these in Logisim / Verilog HDL)
o	Data Transfer schemes: serial, parallel, handshake-based
●	Introduction to Pipelining: Arithmetic Pipeline; Instruction Pipeline; Pipeline hazards and solutions●	Basic Flynn’s taxonomy for parallel processing; Introduction to parallel processing and vector processing

name: Hardware Description Language Laboratory
prerequisite: ENR107 Digital Electronics and Microprocessors [2624]

name: Semiconductor Device Electronics
prerequisite: Additional Instructions: EEE301: Electric Circuits and Network
description: This course focuses on the concepts of Semiconductor Device Electronics. The course begins with Semiconductor Fundamentals, Energy Band Diagrams, Carrier Mobility and Scattering, Carrier Distribution, Equilibrium Carrier Concentration, and Continuity Equation. These concepts are applied to PN Junction Diode to discuss PN Junction Electrostatics, Ideal I-V Characteristics, and Deviation from Ideal Characteristics. The course extends the understanding of the PN junction diode to Bipolar Junction Transistors (BJT) and covers BJT Static Characteristics, Ideal Transistor Analysis and Deviation from Ideal Characteristics. The Metal-Oxide-Semiconductor (MOS) structure is studied with the focus on MOS Capacitor Energy Band Diagrams, Electrostatics, Major Regions of Operation, and Non-idealities in MOS structure. The learning is then extended to MOS Field Effect Transistor (MOSFET) to study qualitative theory of MOSFET Operation, Derivation of ideal I-V Characteristics, Deviation from ideal characteristics and Introduction to the  MOSFET Scaling. Selected Modern Aspects of MOSFET are covered towards the end of the course.

name: ELECTRICAL CIRCUITS AND NETWORKS
description: This is an in depth course for electrical circuits and networks. It buiids upon the previous course ENR 207 (Electric and magnetic circuits). The topic of transient response will be studied in detail for first order as well as higher order circuits.Detailed study of Laplace transform as applied to electrical circuits will be undertaken. Pole zero concepts and their applications will be introduced

name: Thesis Problem Statement
description: The course is designed for M.Tech. CSE students' Master’s thesis who will be working on their project at any external institute (or company) or internally at Ahmedabad University. If the project is external, the student will be assigned a SEAS Faculty member as a co-mentor. In this course, the students will detail the solution approach and methods to be used to solve the problem.  The students will also explain and discuss the preliminary results found.

name: MTech CSE Thesis: Implementation Details and Comparative Evaluations
description: The course is designed for M.Tech. CSE students' Master’s thesis who will be working on their project at any external institute (or company) or internally at Ahmedabad University. If the project is external, the student will be assigned a SEAS Faculty member as a co-mentor. In this course, the students will explain the technical details of their implementation, and do comparative evaluation and analysis of their approach with prior art.

name: MTech CSE Thesis: Results and Comprehensive Report
description: The course is designed for M.Tech. CSE students' Master’s thesis who will be working on their project at any external institute (or company) or internally at Ahmedabad University. If the project is external, the student will be assigned a SEAS Faculty member as a co-mentor. In this course, the students will analyse the results, discuss limitations and outline future work. Also, they will compile a comprehensive report and present their research.

name: Introduction to Data Science
description:
This interdisciplinary university wide first year data science provides an introductory overview of the field, bringing together the foundational concepts from computer science, mathematics, and statistics with practical applications in various disciplines. 

The course aims to equip students with the skills to 
•	collect, clean, analyse, and interpret data, 
•	complement their pursuit of more advanced studies or careers in various domains
•	apply Data Science skills to contribute towards solving inter-disciplinary real-world problems.
This course provides a broad introduction to this fast-emerging field, combining elements of mathematics, statistics, computer science, and domain-specific knowledge. Students will be exposed to the fundamental concepts in data analysis, programming, and machine learning, preparing them for more specialized study in data science or related fields.  The emphasis on the concepts is mostly at an intuitive level to make it accessible to a broader spectrum of students. Hence, students will be exposed to concepts through illustrations, hands-on exercises and case studies that attempts to provide a high-level view of the data lifecycle and its application across various disciplines. These applications are not limited to solving problems in computer science, statistics, and maths but is used to solve problems in arts, economics, medicine, education, and the humanities.

name: Advances in Complex Networks
prerequisite: MAT142 Introductory Calculus [2320]AND ENR106 Introduction to Programming [2684]ORMAT281 Multivariable Calculus [1920]AND ENR106 Introduction to Programming [2684]
description: Advances in Complex Networks will be based on the latest research and developments in complex networks, as well as their applications to various areas, including both natural and technological networks. In particular, the course will be comprised of the following topics: (i) fundamental concepts of graph theory, (ii) understanding the formulation and applications of various complex network-based metrics, (iii) various complex network models and their characteristics, (iv) graph signal processing on complex networks, and (v) study of various real-world complex networks, which include communication networks (wired and wireless), transportation networks (road, rail, and air), supply chain management networks, education networks, social networks, ecological networks, biological networks, economic networks, and healthcare-allied networks, to name a few. In addition, the students must complete a research project (solo or group activity) as part of the course.

name: Separation Processes
prerequisite: CHE315 Mass Transfer [2943]ORCHE204 Mass Transfer Operations - I [633]ORCHE205 Chemical Technology and Calculations [2613]ORENR205 Thermodynamics - I [333]AND CHE221 Thermodynamics - II [642]
description: This course introduces advanced mass transfer operations essential to chemical and environmental engineering practice. It covers the principles, design, and applications of stage-wise and continuous separation processes, including distillation, liquid–liquid extraction, leaching, and adsorption. Students will learn equilibrium concepts, material balances, and stage-wise calculations to analyze and design separation equipment. Emphasis is placed on industrial and environmental applications such as solvent recovery, pollutant removal, and resource utilization. By integrating theory with design methods, the course prepares students to evaluate, select, and optimize separation processes for sustainable chemical and environmental engineering operations.

name: Physical and Chemical Treatment Processes
prerequisite: CHE101 Physical Chemistry [2696]ORCHE100 The World of Chemical and Environmental Engineering [2612]ORCHE207 Environmental Systems Engineering [2780]
description: This course covers concepts of physical and chemical processes relevant to engineered and natural environmental systems, and it combines lectures with laboratory and practical hours to reinforce theoretical understanding through hands-on experience. Topics include colloidal chemistry, DLVO theory, coagulation and flocculation, mechanisms of particle removal in filters and adsorption, disinfection, and advanced treatment processes such as membranes and advanced oxidation, air pollution control strategies and demo-experiments with sophisticated analytical instrumentation.

name: Engineering Electromagnetics
prerequisite: EEE201 Fields and Waves [2926]
description: This course covers the principles of microwave engineering and transmission lines with emphasis on electromagnetic wave propagation, impedance matching, waveguides, and microwave components. Students will learn theoretical foundations along with laboratory exposure to measurements and analysis using modern tools and equipment.

name: Unit Operations and Industry 4.0 Lab
prerequisite: ENR310 Fluid Mechanics and Convective Heat Transfer [2777]AND ENR311 Heat Transfer and Applications [2937]
description: This course constitutes a practical laboratory component focusing on Heat Transfer, Fluid Mechanics, and Mass Transfer. Specifically designed to offer students a hands-on encounter with the essential aspects of these three core chemical engineering courses, it goes beyond theoretical learning. Participants will gain practical insights into the intricacies of the subjects, fostering not only individual understanding but also emphasizing the importance of group coordination and safety practices.

name: ENERGY SYSTEMS AND SUSTAINABILITY LABORATORY
prerequisite: ENR208 Engineering Thermodynamics [2620]
description: This course builds up on concepts and device level analysis of energy conversion systems, based on thermodynamics fundamentals. System level analysis, basics and application based, of power systems, combined cycle power plants, co- and tri-generation cycles will be introduced and this will be connected with primary energy sources utilization. Analysis of refrigeration cycles, VCR and VAM will be introduced. Fuel cell and electrolyser analysis and their engineering implications will be covered. Integration of these systems with renewables (solar, waste-to-heat, etc.) will be explored. The work will be hands-on in project mode. Issues of sustainability, carbon footprint, energy resources utilization, and societal issues will be built into the exercises

name: Catalytic and Biochemical Reaction Engineering
prerequisite: CHE310 Chemical Reaction Engineering [318]
description:
Chemical reaction engineering is a field of chemical engineering focused on designing and operating chemical reactors to optimize chemical reactions on a commercial scale. It integrates concepts of kinetics, transfer processes, thermodynamics, stoichiometry, material and energy balances with reactor design to achieve desired conversion, yield, and selectivity while ensuring safety and economic viability. It is fundamental to many industrial processes, including: Chemical manufacturing, Pharmaceutical production, Waste treatment, and Nanotechnology. 
The present course will focus on heterogenous processes and biochemical processes.

name: Materials and Manufacturing Processes Laboratory
prerequisite: MEC207 Materials and Manufacturing Processes-I [2920]ORMEC208 Materials and Manufacturing Processes-II [2922]
description: The course is structured as a 1-credit lecture and 3-credit laboratory course. Every week, the lecture session will deliver topics relevant to the hands-on activities that will follow in the week. The lecture session will also provide an opportunity to discuss among the student groups about the challenges faced while experimenting and their successful engineering solutions. The students will begin by learning to operate various manufacturing tools (lathe, milling, drilling, laser machining, welding, casting, moulding, forming) with different materials (metals, polymers, woods, composites, ceramics, glass). In subsequent weeks, metrology, product quality, automation in manufacturing, computer-integrated manufacturing (CIM) systems, and competitive aspects of product design and manufacturing will be delivered. Group project work will begin from the fourth week, where students will build a component (or an entire product), or an experimentation setup, or a machine by experimenting to manufacture it using different materials but the same process, and/or by manufacturing it using the same material but different processes. The students will draw conclusions in aspects of design, assembly, dimensions, materials, manufacturing processes, performance, etc., which will be evaluated at different stages during the semester.

name: Mechatronics and Robotics
prerequisite: ENR213 Control Engineering Fundamentals [2921]AND ENR312 Control Engineering Laboratory [2923]
description: This course provides third-year mechanical engineering students with a comprehensive introduction to the synergistic field of mechatronics and robotics. It covers the fundamental building blocks of intelligent systems, including sensors, actuators, and methods for signal conditioning, data acquisition, programmable logic controllers, pneumatics and machine vision. Weekly lab sessions and a team design project lead students through prototyping, debugging, testing and performance evaluation. The course prepares students to design, implement and validate affordable mechatronic and robotic solutions aligned to manufacturing and service applications.

name: Computer Networks
prerequisite: CSE100 Fundamentals of Computer Programming [1146]ORCSE206 Computer Organization and Architecture [1438]ORCSE404 Operating Systems [2965]
description: This is a first course on computer networks. It introduces the fundamentals of computer networking and a number of protocols. The broad topics covered are the layered architecture, physical, data link, network, transport and application layers. It describes the functionalities of these layers as well as the main protocols pertaining to these layers. The course emphasizes the architecture and protocols used in the Internet.

name: Process Synthesis and Integration
prerequisite: CHE301 Heat Transfer [370]AND CHE203 Heat Transfer [628]
description: This course will communicate a strategy for design of integrated production systems with focus on energy efficiency.  Relatively new and systematic methods are lectured for analysis and design of thermally driven separation Systems, Heat exchanger networks and utility systems (consumption and production of thermal and mechanical energy).  Based on new insight about the energy flow in such systems, simple rules are established for correct integration.  The course presents the pinch method for analysis and design of process and energy systems where thermal energy is important.  The course covers both design of new plants ("Grassroots") and retrofit of existing plants for improved energy efficiency.

name: Catalysis and Catalytic Processes
description: Study of catalysts and catalytic process is highly interdisciplinary in nature combining the concepts and applications from domains such as Chemistry, ChemicalEngineering and Material Science. This course covers the fundamentals of catalysis and has been designed to cater the need of students coming from these diverse areas. This course includes basic modes of catalytic action, classification and key concepts, Industrial applications of catalysts, desired characteristics, synthesis and characterization techniques as well as kinetics of catalytic reactions.Course Content includes:  1. Classification and introduction to catalysis2. Surface chemistry3. Materials perspective4. Analytical aspects5. Reactivity and Kinetics of catalytic reactions6. Mechanistic aspects7. Hands on laboratory based experiments on catalysis

name: Data Analytics and Visualisation
prerequisite: CSC100 Introduction to Computer Programming [347]AND CSC250 Database Management Systems/CSE250 Database Management Systems [650]
description: Data Analytics is the science of analyzing data to convert information to useful knowledge. This knowledge could help us understand our world better, and in many contexts enable us to make better decisions. While this is the broad and grand objective, the last 20 years has seen steeply decreasing costs to gather, store, and process data, creating an even stronger motivation for the use of empirical approaches to problem solving. This course seeks to present you with a wide range of data analytic techniques and is structured around the broad contours of the different types of data analytics, namely, descriptive, inferential, predictive, and prescriptive analytics.

name: Technical Communication
description:
The course introduces the world of technical communication by leveraging the following four tracks:
Track 1: Reading and writing comprehension of technical manuscripts (e.g., article, report, thesis/book, and technical manual)Track 2: Understanding tools and techniques for effective communicationTrack 3: Making and delivering technical presentationsTrack 4: Writing a thorough survey on a chosen topic (group activity)Track 1 deals with the following: searching and narrowing existing literature on a particular topic, techniques to further narrow down the literature, reading existing literature and making a summarized version of it, writing a literature survey, identifying open research issues, and further narrowing the literature to identify candidate technique/process (if any) to be compared with the newly developed techniques/process. A basic understanding of utilizing software, which includes Grammarly and Turnitin, will also be introduced for effective writing and removing general and AI text similarities. At the end of Track 1, participants will identify a research direction (based on their interest) and shortlist papers based on the lessons learned. In addition, Track 1 will also investigate the understanding and writing/editing of a technical manual.Track 2 introduces tools and techniques for easy manuscript development and collaborative writing. In particular, Track 2 introduces LaTeX, Gnuplot, and various technical drawing tools (primarily open source tools) for idea development, productive technical writing, and presentation without consuming more time for placement of figures and tables, writing mathematical equations, generating bibliographies, and generating vectorized figures.Track 3 develops the basics of effective technical presentations, making presentations (LaTeX is preferred), slide organization, content design of a slide, delivering talks, highlighting takeaways, ending a presentation, and attending questions from the audience; one technical seminar to be delivered during the Track 3 activity.Track 4 is a group activity where a group of participants (based on the class strength) will be given a topic of their technical area of interest (where they want to pursue research). The participants need to write a survey based on the selected research papers. Track 4 activity will be scattered throughout the course duration.

name: Database Management Systems
prerequisite: Additional Instructions: Basic knowledge of programming is required.
description: This is a core course which covers concepts of relational database management such as entity relationship approach, database system architecture, logical and physical database designing, transaction management, concurrency control and query optimization. It also covers database programming.

name: Software Engineering
description: This course introduces the fundamental principles and practices of software engineering. Students will gain an understanding of the software development lifecycle, software design principles, and an introduction to testing methodologies. They will also learn to apply these concepts in developing real-world software applications.

name: Big Data Analytics
prerequisite: CSE305 Data Structures [2615]ORCSE205 Data Structures [1286]
description: The explosion of social media and the computerization of every aspect of social and economic activity resulted in creation of large volumes of mostly unstructured data: web logs, videos, speech recordings, photographs, e-mails, Tweets, and similar. In a parallel development, computers keep getting ever more powerful and storage ever cheaper. Today, we have the ability to reliably and cheaply store huge volumes of data, efficiently analyze them, and extract business and socially relevant information. The key objective of this course is to familiarize the students with most important information technologies used in manipulating, storing, and analyzing big data.

name: Advanced Statistics
prerequisite: MAT202 Probability and Random Processes [666]
description: This course  is organized into three parts. The first part introduces descriptive statistics, probability, distributions and convergence of random variables. The second part introduces sampling, experiment design and resampling methods. The third part introduces inference and learning from data where it covers topics such as parametric inference, hypothesis testing, statistical learning, regression and classification. The course will have two projects where the first project gives the students a taste of real-world data collection and statistical analysis, and the second project gives experience with statistical learning using real-world datasets. Students will use software to implement and experiment with the concepts taught in the course.

name: Introduction to Blockchain: Technologies, Approaches and Applications
prerequisite: CSE205 Data Structures [1286]ORCSC250 Database Management Systems/CSE250 Database Management Systems [650]
description: Blockchain is considered disruptive and game-changer solution in areas that involve multiple stakeholders, each having complex business processes implemented in unique systems and infrastructure; operating in different administrative and geopolitical boundaries. With cross-organization workflows and complex compliance requirements, industry sectors like Healthcare, Finance, Manufacturing, International Trade, Insurance, Retail, Supply Chain, Recruitment, Media, Real-estate, and Education etc. can benefit significantly by improved operational efficiency, enhanced security, and transparency offered by blockchain implementation.    However, Blockchain technology practices and research activities are currently in initial phase and evolving continuously with new tools, technologies, approaches and application strategies. In such scenario, it is difficult for students, researchers or practitioners to get right entry into the subject. This course will be instrumental in developing familiarity with theoretical concepts, underlying technology, tools, implementation strategies and current practices.  The course will offer detailed overview of two major technology stacks, along with detailed technical discussion on application and research areas.

name: Organic Chemistry
description:
This course is designed to provide a fundamental overview of organic chemistry to
students interested in pursuing a career in science. Upon successful completion of this
class, students will understand the relationship between structure and function of
molecules, the major classes of reactions, reaction energetics and mechanisms,
synthesis of organic compounds, and how to determine structure via various
spectroscopic techniques.

name: Statistics for Engineers
prerequisite: CSD102 Data Science [1164]
description: Statistics has applications in several aspects of engineering, such as, data interpretation, uncertainty analysis in experiments, quality control, machine learning, and simulations of networks amongst others. Topics include fundamentals of linear and introduction to multivariable regression, hypothesis testing, analysis of variance, design of experiments, and simulation. Applications will be drawn from engineering experiments, quality control, sampling, numerical integration, and traffic analysis in data networks. The exercises will require use of Python or any other programming language.

name: Fluid Mechanics and Convective Heat Transfer
Solid-Fluid Operations
prerequisite: CHE100 The World of Chemical and Environmental Engineering [2612]AND ENR210 Continuum Mechanics [2619]AND MAT103 Calculus [1358]
description: Solid-Fluid Operations course is a major core course in Chemical and Environmental Engineering Major. It concentrates on state-of- the-art technology usedparticulate Technology parts such as particle analysis, size reduction & size separation. The course will also cover the solid liquid and solid gas separation

name: Chemical and Bio-Chemical Engineering Thermodynamics
prerequisite: ENR208 Engineering Thermodynamics [2620]
description: This course introduces the concepts of thermodynamics with applications to chemical and biochemical engineering. Chemical processes are designed at industrial level if the equilibrium state of the processes is known. The course highlights the equilibrium concept, effects of parameters on equilibrium as well as change in equilibrium. It describes several methodologies to predict the equilibrium theoretically ideal and non-ideal solution.

name: Environmental Systems Engineering
prerequisite: CHE100 The World of Chemical and Environmental Engineering [2612]AND ENR113 Chemistry in the Engineering World [2614]
description: The course will provide a practical appreciation towards the design and evaluation of environmental engineering systems including conceptualization and formulation of system frameworks for optimal design and evaluation of water supply systems and wastewater treatment systems, source apportionment and air quality monitoring and control systems, and collection and transport systems for solid waste management. Knowledge, skills and competency required to develop optimal design of sustainable environmental engineering systems will be imparted through lectures, case studies, and practical exercises. Relevant examples such as the Sabarmati riverfront project, Namami Gange, New Delhi’s air pollution control measures, integrated solid waste management system in Indore will be discussed.

name: Object Oriented Programming
prerequisite: CSE103 The World of Computer Science and Engineering [2677]AND ENR106 Introduction to Programming [2684]
description: This course provides hands-on experience with object-oriented programming (OOP) concepts and principles. Students will apply their understanding of OOP concepts to practical exercises, enhancing their programming skills. The course will enable students to design and develop object-oriented programs using high-level programming languages like C++ and Java.

name: The World of a Mechanical Engineer
description: This course gives a broad overview of how mechanical engineering manifests in applications ranging from energy, transport, health care, agriculture, energy sources, textiles, construction, etc. Starting from a systems approach, exposure will be given to functioning, and functioning of each equipment in the system. Instructions will be imparted using equipment, models, animations, simulations and engineering drawings. The impact of technologies on environment, health and on society will be brought out.

name: Mechanics of solids and designing with materials
prerequisite: ENR108 Materials and the Engineering World [2623]AND ENR203 Material Science and Engineering [1289]AND ENR209 Mechanics of Rigid Bodies [2625]AND ENR210 Continuum Mechanics [2619]
description: This course imparts the knowledge of basics of solid mechanics and their application in the context of designing machines. It integrates theoretical concepts with practical insights, emphasizing the interdisciplinary nature of these subjects. Students will delve into the mechanics of materials, and structural analysis thereby developing the skills necessary for innovative and efficient machine design. Use of CAD and FEM packages will be integrated into product design.

name: Mechanics of Machines, Vibrations and Structures
description: This course focuses on machines, mechanisms and their kinematics and dynamics. The modelling of the motion of components in a mechanism is discussed with kinematic diagrams and inversions, degrees of freedom, velocity and acceleration analysis using CAD tools, for mechanisms, such as, cam, gear trains, flywheels, engine mechanism, robot mechanisms, etc. Free and forced vibration of single degree of freedom systems is covered. Laboratory work will be hands-on in assembling and using various mechanisms and making measurements using sensors, exercises on balancing, and vibration analysis.

name: Design and Analysis of Algorithms
prerequisite: CSE203 Object Oriented Programming [2782]AND CSE211 Discrete Mathematics [2781]ORCSC210 Introduction to Data Structures and Algorithms [1811]ORCSE107 Object Oriented Programming and Data Structure Lab [1212]AND MAT101 Discrete Mathematics [656]
description: The course provides an introduction to the techniques of the design and analysis of algorithms. It contains the following main themes: 1. Basics: RAM Model;2. Algorithms using graphs and trees;3. Divide and Conquer algorithms;4. Greedy algorithms;5. Dynamic programming;6. NP and Computational intractability;7. Approximation algorithms.

name: Study design and proposal writing for population based research
description: This course focuses on designing population-based research studies and proposal development. It covers a wide range of topics from formulating research questions that stem from societal problems, conducting literature reviews to understand gaps, and designing different types of observational studies and intervention studies. Students will alongside write sections of a research proposal.

name: Environmental Health
description:
There are two sections. The course starts with the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs), which highlight global priorities for environmental protection and public health. This sets the context for the second part of the course, where students learn how specific environmental exposures affect health and how to assess risks, study pollutants, and think about practical solutions.Section 1: SDGs:
This is an interdisciplinary course focusing broadly on the the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) set by the UNEP, with a specific focus on environmental, health, and urban sustainability issues. Each session will focus on a thematic area and discuss the drivers of change, solutions and enabling factors using global case studies.

Section 2: Impact of Environment on Health:
This course explores the impact of environmental factors on human health, covering topics such as air and water pollution, toxicology, climate change, and occupational hazards. Students will learn about exposure pathways, measurement techniques, health risks and mitigation strategies. A lab visit will introduce students to modern analytical techniques/methods used in environmental pollution assessment.

name: Epidemiological Data Analysis
prerequisite: STA501 Applied Statistics [2810]
description: This course introduces students to advanced statistical methods and data analysis techniques in epidemiology. It covers a range of topics from basic descriptive statistics to complex models. The course includes practical applications and projects that use real-world data to solve epidemiological problems.

name: Food and your life stages
description: This course introduces students to nutritional requirements at critical life stages and healthy recipes to address the dietary requirements of the critical life stages including pregnancy and lactation, infancy, childhood, adolescence, adulthood, and older adulthood. The course includes practical sessions i.e., developing life skills – culinary skills (e.g. steaming, sauteing, baking) through innovative healthy recipe preparation using indigenous food ingredients. Additionally, this course has the potential to inspire students to build their own food establishments (e.g. cloud kitchen, restaurant).

name: An Introduction to Infectious Disease Modelling
prerequisite: Additional Instructions: Mathematics at the XI-XII level or approval from the instructor.
description:
This course covers the theory and practice of mathematical modeling in the epidemiology of infectious diseases. It provides students with the tools to understand how infections spread, how interventions influence epidemic trends, and how models can help with public health decisions. Starting with the basics of transmission dynamics, students will learn how to create, analyze, and simulate compartmental models like the SI, SIS, and SIR frameworks. More complex topics will be introduced, including diseases with long incubation periods, vector-borne transmission, and models with seasonality, using case studies of diseases such as tuberculosis, measles, dengue, influenza, COVID-19, and HIV. 

A key focus is on the reproduction number, force of infection, and epidemic thresholds, along with methods for estimating these figures from data. The course highlights model building as a process that consists of: (a) turning biological questions into mathematical frameworks, (b) examining model behavior, (c) calibrating against real-world data, and (d) evaluating the effects of interventions like vaccination, quarantine, or vector control.

Students will gain practical experience through R-based sessions that include simulation, model fitting, and inference. By the end of the course, participants will be able to critically assess infectious disease models in scientific literature and create comprehensive models to address research and policy questions.
